title: Nike hands CEO Mark Parker $30m to stay for five years
text:

Tue, Jul 21, 2015, 18:10 BST - UK Markets closed Nike hands CEO Mark Parker $30m to stay for five years By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 48 minutes ago 363.37 0.00 
Nike (Sao Paolo: NIKE34.SA - news ) , the American sportswear giant, has awarded it chief executive 10 times his typical bonus on the condition he stays for another five years 
Nike, the US sportswear goliath , has handed its long-serving chief executive a $30m (£19m) award to stay for the next five years. 
The award means that Mark Parker, who has been chief executive of the athletics business since 2006, has been handed ten times his typical annual share bonus. 
The Nike veteran started at the company as a shoe designer in 1979 and has worked his way through various roles in marketing and design. 
Mr Parker has been chosen as the successor to chairman Phil Knight who started the business as Blue Ribbon Sports in 1964. Mr Knight, who set the standard for endorsing athletes including basketballer Michael Jordan, has said that he will step down some time next year. 
Last year the US sports group granted Mr Parker, 59, a $10,000 bonus in honour of his 35th year of employment. 
His salary also increased by 15pc to $16.9m when share incentive awards kicked in related to the group's improved financial performance. 
Nike was the England team shirt sponsor during the World Cup 
Nike sales last year grew by 14pc to $40.6bn. 
Mr Parker found himself the target of rap star Kanye West in 2014 who said the Nike boss had "lost culture" before launching into a rage against the US sportswear giant . Mr West, who designed a sell-out range of Nike red Yeezies trainers - has since signed a partnership with rival Adidas (Other OTC: ADDDF - news ) . 
Nike disclosed Mr Parker's future bonus in a stock market filing which said: "In view of the company’s strong performance under Mr Parker’s leadership and to provide an incentive for Mr Parker to stay for at least the next five years, on June 30, 2015, the committee granted to Mr. Parker the opportunity to earn a restricted stock unit award with a target value of $30m representing 277,727 shares of our Class B Stock based on the closing price on the grant date. 
"60pc of the award’s maximum value is based on the Company’s performance, and also will not be earned unless Mr Parker remains employed with the company." 
Earlier this year the sportswear giant set Back to the Future (LSE: FUTR.L - news ) fans' hearts racing when it revealed that it was working on self-tying trainers.
